analysisSummary.summaryText: Analysis Complete — 9 key issues found. ⚠️  Found 9 illegal clause(s) that violate Massachusetts law | ⚡ Identified 11 risky term(s) that could be problematic | ✓ Found 5 tenant-favorable provision(s) | Power Imbalance Score: 100/100 (Concerning)

highlights.category: Chapter 186, Section 15E
highlights.text: The [NAME_REDACTED]ses are delivered to [NAME_REDACTED] and [NAME_REDACTED] accepts the [NAME_REDACTED]ses in their present condition, “AS IS,” it being agreed that [NAME_REDACTED] has had a n opportunity to examine and inspect the [NAME_REDACTED]ses in all respects, that [NAME_REDACTED] has made no representations or warranties of any kind with respect thereto, and that [NAME_REDACTED] shall have no obligation to do any work on, or make any improvements to the [NAME_REDACTED] ses or the condition thereof.
highlights.explanation: This "AS IS" clause could be interpreted as the tenant waiving their right to hold the landlord responsible for defects existing at the time of the letting, especially if those defects violate the building code. Chapter 186, Section 15E explicitly states that a landlord cannot raise the existing defect as a defense and that any waiver of this provision is void and unenforceable.

highlights.category: Chapter 186, Section 15B(1)(c)
highlights.text: 4.5. Interest. All payments becoming due under this [NAME_REDACTED]se and not paid when due s hall bear interest from the applicable due date until received by [NAME_REDACTED] at an annual rate equal to the prime rate of interest charged from time to time by [ORG_REDACTED] or its successor, plus two percent (2%).
highlights.explanation: This clause allows for the imposition of interest on late rent payments *before* 30 days have passed since the rent was due. Chapter 186, Section 15B(1)(c) explicitly prohibits imposing any interest or penalty for failure to pay rent until 30 days after the rent is due. Any such provision is against public policy and void.

highlights.category: Chapter 186, Section 15
highlights.text: 9.2. Release.  To the maximum extent this [NAME_REDACTED]se may be made effective according to law, [NAME_REDACTED] agrees to use and occupy the [NAME_REDACTED]s es at [NAME_REDACTED]'s own risk, and [NAME_REDACTED] shall have no responsibility or liability for any loss or damage to fixtures or other personal property of [NAME_REDACTED] or any person claiming by, through or under [NAME_REDACTED].  Without limitation, [NAME_REDACTED] agrees that [NAME_REDACTED] sha ll not be responsible or liable to [NAME_REDACTED], or those claiming by, through or under [NAME_REDACTED], for any loss or damage resulting to [NAME_REDACTED] or those claiming by, through or under [NAME_REDACTED], its or their property from the breaking, bursting, stopping or leaking of [ORG_REDACTED] and wires, and water, gas or steam pipes.
highlights.explanation: This clause attempts to release the landlord from liability for damage to the tenant's property, including damage from the landlord's negligence. This is an illegal exculpatory clause under Massachusetts law. Landlords have a duty to maintain the premises in a safe condition, and they cannot contractually waive liability for their own negligence.

highlights.category: Chapter 186, Section 15
highlights.text:
9.1. Indemnification.  [NAME_REDACTED] shall, during the term hereof, assume and maintain exclusive control of 
the [NAME_REDACTED]ses and defend, indemn ify and save harmless [NAME_REDACTED] from and against all claims, expenses 
or liability of whatever nature arising from any act, omission or negligence of [NAME_REDACTED], [NAME_REDACTED]'s 
contractors, agents, employees, customers, and invitees, or anyone claiming by, through or  under 
[NAME_REDACTED], or arising, directly or indirectly, from any accident, injury or damage whatsoever, however 
caused, to any person, or to the property of any person, occurring after [NAME_REDACTED] enters the [NAME_REDACTED]ses for 
any reason and until the end of the term of t his [NAME_REDACTED]se and, thereafter, so long as [NAME_REDACTED] or any occupant 
claiming under [NAME_REDACTED] is in occupancy of any part of the [NAME_REDACTED]ses, in or about the [NAME_REDACTED]ses, or arising 
from any accident occurring outside the [NAME_REDACTED]ses but within the general area of the [NAME_REDACTED]se s, where 
such accident, injury or damage results or is claimed to have resulted from any act, omission or 
negligence on the part of [NAME_REDACTED] or [NAME_REDACTED]'s contractors, agents, employees, customers, and invitees, or 
anyone claiming by, through or under [NAME_REDACTED].
highlights.explanation: This clause requires the tenant to indemnify the landlord from claims, expenses, or liability arising from the negligence or misconduct of the landlord, their contractors, agents, etc. This directly violates M.G.L. c. 186, § 15, which prohibits lease provisions that indemnify the landlord for their own negligence.

highlights.category: Chapter 186, Section 15
highlights.text:
9.2. Release.  To the maximum extent this [NAME_REDACTED]se may be made effective according to law, [NAME_REDACTED] 
agrees to use and occupy the [NAME_REDACTED]s es at [NAME_REDACTED]'s own risk, and [NAME_REDACTED] shall have no responsibility or 
liability for any loss or damage to fixtures or other personal property of [NAME_REDACTED] or any person claiming 
by, through or under [NAME_REDACTED].  Without limitation, [NAME_REDACTED] agrees that [NAME_REDACTED] sha ll not be responsible 
or liable to [NAME_REDACTED], or those claiming by, through or under [NAME_REDACTED], for any loss or damage resulting to 
[NAME_REDACTED] or those claiming by, through or under [NAME_REDACTED], its or their property from the breaking, bursting, 
stopping or leaking of [ORG_REDACTED] and wires, and water, gas or steam pipes.
highlights.explanation: This clause attempts to release the landlord from liability for loss or damage to the tenant's property, even if caused by the landlord's negligence (e.g., leaking pipes).  This is an exculpatory clause prohibited under M.G.L. c. 186, § 15.

highlights.category: Potentially a violation of Chapter 93A if unreasonable or used to unfairly burden the tenant.
highlights.text:
10.1  [NAME_REDACTED] Insurance.  [NAME_REDACTED] shall obtain and keep in force at its own expense so long as this 
[NAME_REDACTED]se remains in effect and thereafter so long as [NAME_REDACTED], or anyone claiming by, through or under 
[NAME_REDACTED], uses or occupies the [NAME_REDACTED]ses or any part thereof, policies of insurance for the benefit of such 
parties, in the amounts, and in the manner and form se t forth in this Section; provided, however, that 
amounts of insurance coverage may from time to time be increased.
highlights.statute: Potentially a violation of Chapter 93A if unreasonable or used to unfairly burden the tenant.
highlights.explanation: While requiring insurance is not inherently illegal, the breadth of the insurance requirement (especially requiring the tenant to maintain insurance even after the lease term if anyone claiming under the tenant occupies the premises) could be deemed unreasonable and an unfair or deceptive practice in violation of Chapter 93A. This is especially true if the landlord already has insurance coverage on the property. The tenant should verify if the landlord requires insurance for the tenant's benefit only or if it also covers the landlord's liability.

highlights.category: Chapter 186, Section 15
highlights.text:
10.3.  [ORG_REDACTED].  [NAME_REDACTED] hereby waives any and all rights of recovery which it might otherwise have against 
[NAME_REDACTED], its agents, employees and other persons for whom [NAME_REDACTED] may be responsible for any loss 
or damage to [NAME_REDACTED] property or improvements in the [NAME_REDACTED]ses whi ch are either required to be 
insured under the terms of this [NAME_REDACTED]se or which [NAME_REDACTED], in the absence of any such requirement, elects to 
insure, notwithstanding that the loss or damage may result from the negligence, willful act or default 
under the terms of this [NAME_REDACTED]se by [NAME_REDACTED], its agents, employees, contractors, or other persons for 
whom [NAME_REDACTED] may be responsible.
highlights.explanation: This is a waiver of subrogation clause that states the tenant waives any rights of recovery against the landlord for damage to the tenant's property, even if the damage is due to the landlord's negligence or willful act. This violates M.G.L. c. 186, § 15.

highlights.category: Chapter 186, Section 15
highlights.text:
[NAME_REDACTED] hereby waives any and all rights of recovery which it might otherwise have against 
[NAME_REDACTED], its agents, employees and other persons for whom [NAME_REDACTED] may be responsible for any loss 
or damage to [NAME_REDACTED] property or improvements in the [NAME_REDACTED]ses whi ch are either required to be 
insured under the terms of this [NAME_REDACTED]se or which [NAME_REDACTED], in the absence of any such requirement, elects to 
insure, notwithstanding that the loss or damage may result from the negligence, willful act or default 
under the terms of this [NAME_REDACTED]se by [NAME_REDACTED], its agents, employees, contractors, or other persons for 
whom [NAME_REDACTED] may be responsible.
highlights.explanation: This clause requires the tenant to waive rights of recovery against the landlord for loss or damage to the tenant's property, even if caused by the landlord's negligence or willful acts. This is an exculpatory clause that attempts to preclude the landlord from liability for their own misconduct, which is against public policy and void under Massachusetts law.

highlights.category: Chapter 186, Section 15
highlights.text:
[NAME_REDACTED] acknowledges and agrees that in no 
event shall [NAME_REDACTED] be liable for any injury, harm or any other loss, cost, expense, demand, claim, or 
have any obligation to repair, replace, improve, restore and/or rebuild, any damage of any kind or 
nature whatsoever to the [NAME_REDACTED]ses or any portion thereof caused by an eminent domain taking or by 
fire, flood or other casualty.
highlights.explanation: This clause attempts to release the landlord from any liability for injury, harm, loss, or damage to the premises caused by eminent domain, fire, flood, or other casualty, effectively shifting the entire risk to the tenant. This is an exculpatory clause that is against public policy and void under Massachusetts law as it precludes liability for negligence or other misconduct of the landlord.

highlights.category: Unclear responsibility and potentially illegal pass-through of taxes for residential leases.
highlights.text: 4.3 [ORG_REDACTED]. [NAME_REDACTED] shall be responsible for any and all taxes,  rates, charges, assessments, license fees, municipal liens, levies, excises, water and sewer charges, fees or other charges, whether general or special, or ordinary or extraordinary, of every kind and nature, including governmental or other impositions, c harged, levied, assessed, or imposed, whether by federal, state, local, or any other public authority, during the Term hereof, in relation to the [NAME_REDACTED]ses, [NAME_REDACTED] personal property, and/ or [NAME_REDACTED] use and operation of the [NAME_REDACTED]ses.
highlights.explanation: This clause is incredibly broad and assigns responsibility to the Tenant for *all* taxes, fees, and charges associated with the property. For a commercial lease this is generally accepted, but could raise issues for a residential lease, particularly related to real estate taxes. While Section 15C allows for tax escalation clauses, there are strict requirements around them, including only increases in taxes being passed on to the tenant, and those increases needing to be proportional. This language appears to sidestep those requirements. This clause could be challenged as unconscionable, or as an unfair and deceptive act under Chapter 93A, particularly if the landlord attempts to pass through a large and unexpected tax bill to the tenant.

highlights.category: Potential ambiguity regarding scope of tenant's maintenance responsibilities.
highlights.text: 6.1. [NAME_REDACTED] Responsibility.  [NAME_REDACTED] shall be responsible for maintaining the [NAME_REDACTED]ses in g ood and clean condition and order at its sole expense.  Without limiting the foregoing, [NAME_REDACTED] shall keep the [NAME_REDACTED]ses, including, without limitation, the electrical fixtures, windows, halls, stairwells, lavatories and all other areas of the Building, the landscaping (including, without limitation, keeping the grass neat and cut and trimming of trees and bushes) in good condition, damage by fire or other casualty, and ordinary wear and tear only excepted.
highlights.explanation: This clause is overly broad in defining the tenant's maintenance responsibilities. While it excepts "damage by fire or other casualty, and ordinary wear and tear," it's not entirely clear what constitutes 'good condition' with respect to 'electrical fixtures, windows, halls, stairwells, lavatories and all other areas of the Building.' This ambiguity could lead to disputes over whether the tenant is responsible for repairs that are beyond the scope of normal wear and tear. A reasonable interpretation is required.

highlights.category: Unclear assignment of repair responsibilities and potential for abuse
highlights.text:
6.4 [NAME_REDACTED] Failure to Maintain.  If any maintenance, repair and/or replacements is required to be 
made by [NAME_REDACTED] pursuant to the terms hereof and [NAME_REDACTED] fails to cure the same within thirty (30) days 
after no tice by [NAME_REDACTED] (or, in the event of an emergency, with such notice as is practicable), [NAME_REDACTED] 
shall have the right (but shall not be obligated) to make such repairs, replacements or perform 
maintenance work or any other work required of [NAME_REDACTED] pursuant  to this [NAME_REDACTED]se and charge the cost 
thereof to [NAME_REDACTED] as [ORG_REDACTED], which, if not paid within thirty (30) days from the presentment of 
invoices therefore, shall bear interest at the rate set forth herein.
highlights.explanation: This clause is problematic because it is vague about who is responsible for what repairs. It states that if '[NAME_REDACTED]' (presumably the tenant) fails to cure maintenance within 30 days after notice, the other party (presumably landlord) *may* make repairs and charge the tenant. The underlying responsibility for specific repairs needs to be clearly delineated elsewhere in the lease. This clause allows the landlord to potentially charge the tenant for repairs that are typically the landlord's responsibility under MA law (implied warranty of habitability). Additionally, the interest rate applied to unpaid invoices needs to be compliant with MA law.

highlights.category: Tenant paying for landlord improvements
highlights.text:
5. [NAME_REDACTED] shall obtain the [NAME_REDACTED]'s written approval prior to 
making any structural alterations or additions to the [NAME_REDACTED]ses.   [NAME_REDACTED] may make non -structural 
alterations or additions to the [NAME_REDACTED]ses, including paving the unp aved, unlined parking area located 
around the Building.  All such allowed or required alterations or additions shall be at [NAME_REDACTED]'s sole 
expense, shall be in accordance with all applicable laws and codes, and shall be in quality at least equal 
to the prese nt construction.
highlights.explanation: This implies the tenant is paying for improvements of the landlord's property which could be considered unfair. Requiring the tenant to pay for such improvements, especially 'required alterations or additions,' needs careful consideration and could be considered a violation of the implied warranty of habitability if those alterations relate to maintaining the premises in a habitable condition. Also, the use of "required alterations or additions" without clear specification could lead to disputes and potentially be deemed unconscionable.

highlights.category: Potential for unreasonable denial of assignment/sublease.
highlights.text:
8.5 Assignment and Subleasing.  [NAME_REDACTED] shall not assign, sublet, underlet, mortgage, pledge or 
encumber (collectively referred to as "[NAME_REDACTED]") this [NAME_REDACTED]se without [NAME_REDACTED]'s prior written consent, 
which may be withheld in [NAME_REDACTED]’s sole discretion.
highlights.explanation: While landlords can restrict assignment and subletting, a clause allowing the landlord to withhold consent in their 'sole discretion' might be interpreted as unreasonable if the landlord has no legitimate reason to deny a suitable replacement tenant. In a commercial context, this is often permissible, but it can be problematic if the landlord is acting arbitrarily or capriciously and creating undue hardship for the tenant. There is an argument for unreasonableness if the lease doesn't clearly define objective criteria for approval.

highlights.category: Overly broad indemnification clause
highlights.text:
9.1. Indemnification.  [NAME_REDACTED] shall, during the term hereof, assume and maintain exclusive control of 
the [NAME_REDACTED]ses and defend, indemn ify and save harmless [NAME_REDACTED] from and against all claims, expenses 
or liability of whatever nature arising from any act, omission or negligence of [NAME_REDACTED], [NAME_REDACTED]'s 
contractors, agents, employees, customers, and invitees, or anyone claiming by, through or  under 
[NAME_REDACTED], or arising, directly or indirectly, from any accident, injury or damage whatsoever, however 
caused, to any person, or to the property of any person, occurring after [NAME_REDACTED] enters the [NAME_REDACTED]ses for 
any reason and until the end of the term of t his [NAME_REDACTED]se and, thereafter, so long as [NAME_REDACTED] or any occupant 
claiming under [NAME_REDACTED] is in occupancy of any part of the [NAME_REDACTED]ses, in or about the [NAME_REDACTED]ses, or arising 
from any accident occurring outside the [NAME_REDACTED]ses but within the general area of the [NAME_REDACTED]se s, where 
such accident, injury or damage results or is claimed to have resulted from any act, omission or 
negligence on the part of [NAME_REDACTED] or [NAME_REDACTED]'s contractors, agents, employees, customers, and invitees, or 
anyone claiming by, through or under [NAME_REDACTED].
highlights.explanation: This indemnification clause is very broad and potentially requires the tenant to indemnify the landlord even for the landlord's own negligence. While indemnification clauses are common, they are scrutinized by courts, especially when they attempt to shift liability for the landlord's own actions onto the tenant. If this clause is interpreted to require the tenant to indemnify the landlord for the landlord's own negligence, it could be challenged as unconscionable and against public policy.

highlights.category: Unclear responsibility for pre-existing hazardous conditions
highlights.text:
8.  [NAME_REDACTED] shall not bring onto, store, release, dispose or threaten the 
release from the [NAME_REDACTED]ses or elsewhere on the [NAME_REDACTED]ses any hazardous, toxic, inflammable, combust ible 
or explosive fluid, material, chemical, or substance, including without limitation any item defined as 
hazardous pursuant Chapter 21E of [ORG_REDACTED] and federal and other state laws 
(“). [NAME_REDACTED] shall defend, ind emnify and hold harmless [NAME_REDACTED], and those 
claiming by, through and under [NAME_REDACTED], from and against any and all liability, loss, damage, costs, 
expenses (including, without limitation, reasonable attorneys’ fees and expenses), causes of action, 
suits, c laims, demands or judgments of any nature in any way suffered, incurred, or paid as a result of 
any release or threatened release of  on or from the [NAME_REDACTED]ses which is caused or 
exacerbated by [NAME_REDACTED], its agents, employees, contractors, representatives, or invitees.  [NAME_REDACTED] shall 
have no responsibility to [NAME_REDACTED], its agents, employees, representatives and invitees, for the presence of 
 on the [NAME_REDACTED]ses or be required to abate or remediate the same.  The provisions 
of this Section shall survive the expiration or earlier termination of the [NAME_REDACTED]se.
highlights.explanation: While the first part is standard and reasonable, the phrase '[NAME_REDACTED] shall have no responsibility to [NAME_REDACTED]... for the presence of [ORG_REDACTED] on the [NAME_REDACTED]ses or be required to abate or remediate the same' is problematic. It potentially absolves the landlord of responsibility for pre-existing hazardous conditions, even if those conditions violate environmental laws and render the premises unsafe. This could be a violation of the implied warranty of habitability and potentially lead to liability under Chapter 93A if the landlord knew about the contamination and failed to disclose it.

highlights.category: Ambiguous language regarding control of the premises.
highlights.text:
9.1. Indemnification.  [NAME_REDACTED] shall, during the term hereof, assume and maintain exclusive control of 
the [NAME_REDACTED]ses
highlights.explanation: The term "exclusive control" is vague. While the tenant has possession, the landlord typically retains certain rights, such as access for repairs. It is important to define the scope of "exclusive control." The vagueness may cause disputes between Landlord and Tenant.

highlights.category: Potential Unfairness regarding responsibility for repairs.
highlights.text:
(c) If any part of the [NAME_REDACTED]ses is damaged by fire or other casualty or is taken by a public 
authority and this [NAME_REDACTED]se is not terminated by [NAME_REDACTED] or [NAME_REDACTED] as provided above, [NAME_REDACTED] shall 
proceed with reasonable diligence to repair and restore the [NAME_REDACTED]ses, or what remains thereof in the 
case of a partial taking, to its condition prior to such t aking.  [NAME_REDACTED] acknowledges and agrees that in no 
event shall [NAME_REDACTED] be liable for any injury, harm or any other loss, cost, expense, demand, claim, or 
have any obligation to repair, replace, improve, restore and/or rebuild, any damage of any kind or 
nature whatsoever to the [NAME_REDACTED]ses or any portion thereof caused by an eminent domain taking or by 
fire, flood or other casualty.
highlights.explanation: While the lease states that the landlord will repair with 'reasonable diligence', the later acknowledgement by the tenant that the Landlord is not liable to repair any damage could create conflict. It's unclear if the 'reasonable diligence' creates an obligation that will actually be met. The Landlord might point to the acknowledgement to refute the obligation.

highlights.category: Potential for increased rent and conflicts over insurance coverage.
highlights.text:
Without limiting [NAME_REDACTED]'s other rights under any other provisions of this 
[NAME_REDACTED]se, if [NAME_REDACTED] shall fail to keep the [NAME_REDACTED]ses insured as provided herein, and if such failure shall 
continue to a period of ten (10) days following written notice by [NAME_REDACTED] to [NAME_REDACTED] thereof, then 
[NAME_REDACTED], without further notice to [NAME_REDACTED], may take out and pay for such insurance, and the amount of 
such payment shall become due and payable as [ORG_REDACTED] on demand.
highlights.explanation: This allows the Landlord to purchase insurance on Tenant's behalf and bill Tenant for it as additional 'rent'. There may be disagreement as to the necessity and cost-effectiveness of insurance coverage. Also, if it is considered 'rent' tenant may face eviction if they fail to reimburse the landlord.

highlights.category: Indemnification Clause potentially shifting liability to tenant
highlights.text:
To the extent 
permitted by law, [NAME_REDACTED] shall indemnify [NAME_REDACTED] dlord against all payments which [NAME_REDACTED] may incur by 
reason of such termination during the residue of the Term.
highlights.explanation: This clause is problematic because it requires the tenant to indemnify the landlord against payments the landlord may incur due to the termination of the lease. This could potentially include legal fees or other expenses arising from a breach by the tenant. While it says 'to the extent permitted by law,' it's still a broad clause that could be interpreted to require the tenant to cover costs that should be the landlord's responsibility. A judge would have to evaluate whether this clause is unconscionable in practice, as it is written very broadly.

highlights.category: Clearly defines landlord's responsibilities for major structural and essential systems repairs and maintenance.
highlights.text: 6.2 [NAME_REDACTED]’s Responsibility.  [NAME_REDACTED] shall be responsible for the electrical wiring and lighting, all plumbing and utility lines serving the [NAME_REDACTED]ses, the heating and ventilating system and the fire protection equipment and syste ms serving the Building, the roof, exterior walls and foundations of the Building, in good and safe order, condition and repair, reasonable wear and tear and damage by fire or other casualty excepted.  [NAME_REDACTED] shall be responsible for removing snow and ice from the [NAME_REDACTED]ses, including all sidewalks, walkways, and parking areas.
highlights.explanation: Clearly defines landlord's responsibilities for major structural and essential systems repairs and maintenance.

highlights.category: Requires 24 hour notice for inspections and that the inspections not unreasonably interfere with the tenant's use of the premises.
highlights.text: 6.3 Inspection.  Without limiting [NAME_REDACTED]’s rights to access the [NAME_REDACTED]ses under other provisions of this [NAME_REDACTED]se, [NAME_REDACTED] hereby specifically reserves the right to conduct an annua l inspection of the [NAME_REDACTED]ses, and [NAME_REDACTED] shall allow entry and access to [ORG_REDACTED], [ORG_REDACTED], and such other persons as [ORG_REDACTED] may designate, for the purpose of investigating the condition of the of the [NAME_REDACTED]s es.  [NAME_REDACTED] shall provide [NAME_REDACTED] with a minimum notice of twenty -four (24) hours, and not interfere unreasonably with [NAME_REDACTED] use of the [NAME_REDACTED]ses.
highlights.explanation: Requires 24 hour notice for inspections and that the inspections not unreasonably interfere with the tenant's use of the premises.

highlights.category: Allows the tenant to terminate the lease if the premises become unusable due to casualty or eminent domain.
highlights.text:
(b) If the [NAME_REDACTED]ses or any portion thereof shall be destroyed or damaged by fire or other casualty, 
or taken by any public or quasi -public agency or authority other than [NAME_REDACTED] by right of eminent 
domain, and the casualty/taking unreasonably interferes with the use of the [NAME_REDACTED]ses for the Permitted 
Uses in a manner comparable to such use prior to such casualty/condemnation, this [NAME_REDACTED] se shall 
terminate at the election of either [NAME_REDACTED] or [NAME_REDACTED].  Any such termination shall be effective thirty 
(30) days after the date of notice thereof.
highlights.statute: Common Law (implied warranty of habitability, though often limited in commercial leases)
highlights.explanation: Allows the tenant to terminate the lease if the premises become unusable due to casualty or eminent domain.

highlights.category: Guarantees tenant's right to quiet enjoyment of the premises.
highlights.text:
[NAME_REDACTED] hereby warrants and covenants that [NAME_REDACTED] shall have peaceful and 
quiet use and possession of the [NAME_REDACTED]ses without hindrance or interruption on the part  of [NAME_REDACTED], or 
by any other person(s) for whose actions [NAME_REDACTED] is legally responsible, or by any person claiming by, 
through or under [NAME_REDACTED], except as herein provided.
highlights.statute: Implied Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment under MA law
highlights.explanation: Guarantees tenant's right to quiet enjoyment of the premises.

highlights.category: Protects the tenant from immediate eviction due to property sale or foreclosure.
highlights.text: A tenancy at will of property occupied for dwelling purposes shall not be terminated by operation of law by the conveyance, transfer or leasing of the premises by the owner or landlord thereof or by foreclosure.
highlights.explanation: Protects the tenant from immediate eviction due to property sale or foreclosure.
